places.name: Terni
places.description: Terni is a city in the southern portion of the region of Umbria in central Italy.

persons.name: Hajani
persons.description: Unidentified

places.name: Palazzo Bolognetti
places.description: Now called the Palazzo Nuñez-Torlonia, a 16th-century Renaissance town house in Via della Conciliazione, Rome, Italy.

places.name: Laura
places.description: A southern Italian village and hamlet of Capaccio, a municipality in the province of Salerno, Campania.

places.name: Paestum
places.description: Paestum was an ancient Greek city on the coast of southern Italy.

places.name: Eboli
places.description: An Italian town in the province of Salerno.

places.name: River Arveyron
places.description: Davy is possibly referring to the rivers Arveyron and Arve: the Arveyron rises just above Chamonix in France and is a tributary of the Arve.

works.name: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Humphry Davy, Bart
works.author: Humphry Davy

persons.name: RobertBoyle
persons.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

places.name: Pont, Côte-d'Or
places.description: Likely a reference to the Pont du Gard, a Roman aqueduct bridge built in the first century AD, located in southern France.

persons.name: Louis BernardGuyton de Morveau
persons.description: French chemist and revolutionary politician who is credited with producing the first systematic method of chemical nomenclature. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: SmithsonTennant
persons.description: Tennant was a botanist and chemist and knew Davy through agricultural improvements. Appointed Professor of Chemistry at Cambridge University in 1813, he was killed in a riding accident in France. FRSL.

persons.name: Antoine-LaurentLavoisier
persons.description: French chemist and tax farmer (for which he was guillotined). Developed a new nomenclature for chemistry (much of which is still in use today) and argued strongly against the existence of phlogiston. Davy read some of his writings while in Cornwall which he then opposed and throughout his career maintained an ambivalent attitude towards Lavoisierian chemisty. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: William HaseldinePepys
persons.description: Pepys was a surgical and scientific instrument maker and chemist. Constructed large batteries used by Davy (amongst others). FRSL.

persons.name: Jean-BaptisteBiot
persons.description: French mathematician, physicist and astronomer; Professor of Physics at the Collège de France. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Dominique François JeanArago
persons.description: French mathematician, physicist, astronomer and political liberal. Davy presented him with the Copley Medal in 1825. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: WilliamAllen
persons.description: Allen was a Quaker who worked in the pharmaceutical industry. Davy asked him to give lectures on natural philosophy at the RI. FRSL.

persons.name: FelicianoScarpellini
persons.description: Italian astronomer and abbot; he served as Master of Logic and Metaphysics at Collegio Romano (the Roman College).

places.name: Florence
places.description: The capital city of the Italian region of Tuscany.

places.name: Tuscany
places.description: a region in central Italy

places.name: Rome
places.description: The capital of Italy.

persons.name: Count GirolamoBardi
persons.description: Italian geologist and mineralogist. He was the director of the Museum of Physics and Natural History of Florence where Davy experimented in 1814.

persons.name: Domenico LinoMorichini
persons.description: Italian physican and chemist. Professor of Chemistry at the Univerity of Rome from 1798 to his death. Gave Davy medical advice in his final years. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: GiuseppeGazzaris
persons.description: (Gazzeri) was an Italian chemist who published Compendio d'un trattato elementare di chimica - a chemistry textbook based on the work of the French Chemists.

places.name: Rome
places.description: The capital of Italy.

persons.name: Daniel GabrielFahrenheit
persons.description: German physicist, inventor, and scientific instrument maker, who invented the mercury-in-glass thermometer. The temperature scale he proposed is named after him. ForMemRSL.

places.name: Carrara
places.description: Carrara is a city in central Italy.

places.name: Bay of Naples
places.description: The Bay (or Gulf) of Naples is located on the south-western coast of Italy, with Naples to the north, Vesuvius to the east, and the Sorrento Peninsula to the south.

places.name: Pontine Marshes
places.description: Now agricultural land, the Pontine Marshes are located south-east of Rome.

places.name: Paestum
places.description: Paestum was an ancient Greek city on the coast of southern Italy.

places.name: Apennines
places.description: The Apennines are a range of mountains that run down the spine of peninsular Italy.

places.name: Lake of Nemi
places.description: A volcanic lake south of Rome, Italy. The lake was sacred to the goddess Diana Nemorensis.

places.name: Cava de' Tirreni
places.description: Monte Cavo (Monte Albano) is an extinct volcano in the Alban Hills, near Rome.

places.name: Caserta
places.description: A city in south-western Italy.

places.name: Naples
places.description: Naples is the regional capital of Campania in Italy. It is located beneath the volcano, Vesuvius.

places.name: Rome
places.description: The capital of Italy.

places.name: Sele River
places.description: The Sele River flows through southwestern Italy and enters the Tyrrhenian Sea close to the ancient city of Paestum.

places.name: Temple of Neptune
places.description: Roman temple located in Paestum, near Naples, Italy.

places.name: Miseno
places.description: A port near Naples, Italy, to the north of the Gulf of Naples.

places.name: Pompeii
places.description: An ancient city located in what is now the comune of Pompei near Naples in the Campania region of Italy. Pompeii was buried in volcanic ash in the Eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 CE.

places.name: Paestum
places.description: Paestum was an ancient Greek city on the coast of southern Italy.

places.name: Salerno
places.description: City in south-western Italy, located on the Gulf of Salerno. Salerno is the capital city of the Italian province also named Salerno, in the Campania region of Italy.

places.name: Herculaneum
places.description: Herculaneum was an ancient Roman town, located in the modern-day comune of Ercolano, Campania, Italy.

places.name: Posillipo, a hill in Naples
places.description: A district of Naples, Italy, built upon a rock peninsula.

places.name: Capri
places.description: An island in the Gulf of Naples, Italy.

places.name: Ischia
places.description: An island in the Gulf of Naples, Italy.

places.name: Mount Vesuvius
places.description: Mount Vesuvius is a somma-stratovolcano located on the Gulf of Naples in Campania, Italy.

places.name: Naples
places.description: Naples is the regional capital of Campania in Italy. It is located beneath the volcano, Vesuvius.

places.name: Mount Somma
places.description: A mountain located in the Province of Naples, in the Campania region of southern Italy. It has a collapsed caldera of an older volcano, with Mount Vesuvius rising up from the center.

places.name: Solfatara Caldera
places.description: Solfatara di Pozzuoli is a volcanic crater near Naples. Though a dormant volcano, it emits jets of steam and sulphurous fumes.

places.name: Theatre of Herculaneum
places.description: An archaeological site, buried by the eruption of Vesuvius in 79 CE and discovered by a farmer in 1709.

places.name: Pompeii
places.description: An ancient city located in what is now the comune of Pompei near Naples in the Campania region of Italy. Pompeii was buried in volcanic ash in the Eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 CE.

places.name: Astroni Crater
places.description: A nature reserve in an extinct volcanic crater near Naples, Italy.

places.name: Cave Lazio
places.description: Subterranean chamber beneath the ancient city of Cumae, now Naples, Italy. Said to have been the dwelling place of Sibyl, ancient priestess and oracle.

places.name: Monte Nuovo
places.description: A cinder cone volcano near Naples, Italy, that first formed in the sixteenth century.

places.name: Grotto del Cane
places.description: A cave by the Lake of Agnano, in southern Italy, that has a high concentration of carbon dioxide. Dogs were used to demonstrate this as a kind of tourist attraction, which the Shelleys refused to allow when they visited.

places.name: Posillipo, a hill in Naples
places.description: A district of Naples, Italy, built upon a rock peninsula.

places.name: Pozzuoli
places.description: A city within the city of Naples, Italy. It is the main city of the Phlegrean Peninsula.

places.name: Columns of Macellum
places.description: The columns contain borings made by the marine bivalve, Lithophaga. This indicated that the columns had been submerged beneath the sea and then uplifted. This observation was included in Charles Lyell's first volume of Principles of Geology, published shortly after Davy's death in 1830.

places.name: Lake of Agnano
places.description: Lake Agnano, in southern Italy, was a lake in the crater of the extinct volcano (Agnano). It was drained in 1870.

persons.name: Barnaba Niccolò Maria LuigiChiaramonti
persons.description: Pope Pius VII, 1800-1823, held prisioner by Buonparte, 1809-1813. In February 1814 Davy and his party stayed in the same inn that Pius had used the week before on his way back to Rome.

places.name: Rome
places.description: The capital of Italy.

places.name: Alps
places.description: The Alps are the highest and most extensive mountain range that lies entirely in Europe. They are located in eight European countries.

places.name: Rhone River
places.description: A major river in France and Switzerland.

places.name: Alps
places.description: The Alps are the highest and most extensive mountain range that lies entirely in Europe. They are located in eight European countries.

places.name: Rhone River
places.description: A major river in France and Switzerland.

places.name: Rhone River
places.description: A major river in France and Switzerland.

persons.name: ClaudeLorrain
persons.description: French painter, who lived mostly in Italy; known for his landscapes. Davy knew of his work, mentioning Lorrain in a letter to Mr Poole included in the memoirs published by his brother, John Davy (Memoirs of the Life of Sir Humphry Davy).

persons.name: FrancescoPetrarch
persons.description: An Italian poet and scholar, famous for his love sonnets. Davy wrote a poem called 'Vaucluse' inspired by Petrarch's poetry on the river Sorgue and Vaucluse valley in the Provence region of France and called him the 'bard of provence' in another poem, which John Davy published with the title 'Banks of the Rhone'.

places.name: Vaucluse
places.description: A department in south-eastern France.

places.name: Montpellier
places.description: A city in southern France.

places.name: Mediterranean Sea
places.description: Connected to the Atlantic Ocean and almost completely surrounded by land.

places.name: River Thames
places.description: The River Thames, known alternatively in parts as the River Isis, is a river that flows through southern England including London.

persons.name: Plato
persons.description: A pupil of Socrates, much of Plato's large corpus of surviving philosophical texts are written in the form of Socratic dialogues. He espoused a philosophical idealism including the primacy of mathematics and an anti-democratic political philosophy because of the execution of Socrates. Plato's writings have been, and are, so influential that all subsequent philosophy has been described as footnotes to Plato.

persons.name: Socrates
persons.description: Greek philosopher whose work survives mostly through the writings of his pupil Plato. Executed by the democratic Athenian state for sedition.

places.name: Bosphorus
places.description: A passage of water in northwestern Turkey that connects the Black Sea to the Mediterranean. Forming part of the border between Asia and Europe, the strait bisects the city of Istanbul.

places.name: Africa
places.description: The world's second-largest and second-most populous continent.

places.name: Vale of Tempe
places.description: 10km long Greek gorge in northern Thessaly. Located between the mountains Ossa and Olympus, the Pineios River flows through the vale.

places.name: Rome
places.description: The capital of Italy.

places.name: Calpe
places.description: A municipality located on the Mediterranean coast of Spain.

places.name: Monte Bolca
places.description: A locality near Verona, Italy, that is an important site for marine fossils, and has been known of since the 16th century.

places.name: Lombardy
places.description: An administrative region of Italy in the north central part of the country.

places.name: Ligurian Hills
places.description: A region in north-western Italy located where the Alps and the Apennines meet.

places.name: Apennines
places.description: The Apennines are a range of mountains that run down the spine of peninsular Italy.

places.name: Mediterranean Sea
places.description: Connected to the Atlantic Ocean and almost completely surrounded by land.

places.name: Desenzano del Garda
places.description: A town in Lombardy located on the shore of Lake Garda.

places.name: Sandy Braes
places.description: Perhaps part of the Tardree Mountain complex, County Antrim, Northern Ireland, a volcanic vent complex with very rare rocks, which belong to the Tardree Rhyolite Complex, or Sallagh Braes, a mountain in County Antrim.

places.name: Verona
places.description: Verona is a city located on the Adige River in the north of Italy.

places.name: Nîmes
places.description: A town in the region of Namur in Belgium, known for its limestone and caves.

persons.name: AlessandroVolta
persons.description: Professor of experimental physics at the University of Pavia. At the end of the eighteenth century he Invented the Voltaic pile which produced electric current and which Davy shortly dubbed the battery. Davy described meeting him in 1814 in notebook 14/I, p.38. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: William HydeWollaston
persons.description: Originally a physician he became a prominent chemist, physicist and physiologist isolating the chemical elements osmium, palladium and rhodium. He made his fortune by developing a method of obtaining metallic platinum. A friend and to some extent a rival of Davy's, in 1820 he served briefly as President of the Royal Society of London between Banks's death and Davy's election. FRSL.

places.name: Adriatic Sea
places.description: The Adriatic Sea lies between the Italian Peninsula and the Balkan Peninsula. It is the northernmost section of the Mediterranean Sea.

places.name: Milan
places.description: A city in northern Italy, and the capital of Lombardy.

places.name: Rimini
places.description: A city in north-eastern Italy located on the coast of the Adriatic Sea.

places.name: Geneva
places.description: Geneva is a city in Switzerland on the border with France.

places.name: Salerno
places.description: City in south-western Italy, located on the Gulf of Salerno. Salerno is the capital city of the Italian province also named Salerno, in the Campania region of Italy.

places.name: Eboli
places.description: An Italian town in the province of Salerno.

persons.name: JohnLubbock
persons.description: Sir John Lubbock, 1st Baronet of Lammas, was a merchant, MP and prominent London banker. He helped establish and was a partner in the bank of Lemon, Buller, Finlay and Lubbock of London in 1772. He was also involved in diverse business ventures as a merchant.

persons.name: GiuseppeGazzaris
persons.description: (Gazzeri) was an Italian chemist who published Compendio d'un trattato elementare di chimica - a chemistry textbook based on the work of the French Chemists.

places.name: Geneva
places.description: Geneva is a city in Switzerland on the border with France.

places.name: Baths of Titus
places.description: Public baths built in Rome in 81 CE by the emperor Titus.

places.name: Porto fino
places.description: A coastal town in north-western Italy, within the city of Genoa.

places.name: Baths of Titus
places.description: Public baths built in Rome in 81 CE by the emperor Titus.

places.name: Porto fino
places.description: A coastal town in north-western Italy, within the city of Genoa.

places.name: Alps
places.description: The Alps are the highest and most extensive mountain range that lies entirely in Europe. They are located in eight European countries.

places.name: Genoa
places.description: Italian port city in northwestern Italy. It is the capital of the Liguria region.

places.name: Rome
places.description: The capital of Italy.

places.name: Baths of Nero
places.description: The Baths of Nero were a complex of Roman baths built in 64 CE.

places.name: Rome
places.description: The capital of Italy.

places.name: Rome
places.description: The capital of Italy.

persons.name: HenryCavendish
persons.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

places.name: Paros
places.description: A Greek island situated in the Mediterranean Sea, famous for its Parian marble: a fine-grained semi translucent pure-white and entirely flawless marble quarried during the classical era .

places.name: Paestum
places.description: Paestum was an ancient Greek city on the coast of southern Italy.

places.name: Pietramala
places.description: A town near Florence, Italy.

places.name: Lake of Agnano
places.description: Lake Agnano, in southern Italy, was a lake in the crater of the extinct volcano (Agnano). It was drained in 1870.

places.name: Adda River
places.description: The Adda is a river in northern Italy and is a tributary of the Po River.

places.name: Grotto del Cane
places.description: A cave by the Lake of Agnano, in southern Italy, that has a high concentration of carbon dioxide. Dogs were used to demonstrate this as a kind of tourist attraction, which the Shelleys refused to allow when they visited.

places.name: Moray Firth
places.description: A  large inlet on the north-east coast of Scotland.

places.name: Albulae Aquae
places.description: White Waters'; a group of springs to the west of Tivolo, Italy, and location of an ancient Roman settlement.

places.name: The Colosseum
places.description: The Colosseum, the largest amphitheatre ever built, is located in the centre of Rome. Now a ruin, its construction began 2,000 years ago.

places.name: Apennines
places.description: The Apennines are a range of mountains that run down the spine of peninsular Italy.

places.name: Iser
places.description: The Isar River originates in the Karwendal mountains of the Alps, flowing through Bavaria in Germany, before reaching the Danube.

places.name: Rhine
places.description: The Rhine is one of Europe's major rivers. It rises in Switzerland, flows through Germany, and enters the North Sea in the Netherlands.

places.name: Carrara
places.description: Carrara is a city in central Italy.

places.name: Bienne River
places.description: A river in eastern France.

places.name: Ticino River
places.description: The most important left-bank tributary of the Po River in Italy.

places.name: Rhone River
places.description: A major river in France and Switzerland.

places.name: Radicofani
places.description: A town in the Province of Siena, Italy.

places.name: Albulae Aquae
places.description: White Waters'; a group of springs to the west of Tivolo, Italy, and location of an ancient Roman settlement.

places.name: Aniene River
places.description: The Aniene is a river rising in the Apennines and flowing west to join the Tiber in northern Rome. It is famous for the Tivoli waterfall.

places.name: Alexandrine Aqueduct
places.description: Also known as the Aquedutto Alexandrina or Aqua Alexandrina. Built in the 3rd century CE to carry water to Rome.

places.name: Nar
places.description: The Nera River. It runs through Romania and Serbia and is a tributary of the Danube.

places.name: Paestum
places.description: Paestum was an ancient Greek city on the coast of southern Italy.

places.name: Apennines
places.description: The Apennines are a range of mountains that run down the spine of peninsular Italy.

places.name: Terni
places.description: Terni is a city in the southern portion of the region of Umbria in central Italy.

places.name: Velino
places.description: A river in central Italy, a tributary of the Nera.

places.name: Rome
places.description: The capital of Italy.

places.name: Siena
places.description: A city in Tuscany, and the capital of the Province of Siena.

places.name: Tivoli, Lazio
places.description: Tivoli is a town north east of Rome and known for the waterfall on the Aniene River.

persons.name: JohnRussell
persons.description: Sixth Duke of Bedford from 1802. A Proprieter of the Royal Institution and member of the Board of Agriculture in which roles he knew Davy.

persons.name: Henry HallGage
persons.description: Fourth Viscount Gage (in the Irish peerage) from 1808.  Met Davy in Rome in 1815 who thereafter stayed with him at his seat Firle Place, near Lewes, several times.

places.name: Malagrotta
places.description: Malagrotta is a nature reserve in the region of Rome, Italy.

places.name: Ostia
places.description: An area in Rome, Italy.

places.name: Pantano Borghese
places.description: On the outskirts of Rome south of Tivoli, an estate that since 1613 has belonged to the Borghese family.

places.name: Marcellina
places.description: Marcellina is a district of Rome, Italy.

persons.name: Henry HallGage
persons.description: Fourth Viscount Gage (in the Irish peerage) from 1808.  Met Davy in Rome in 1815 who thereafter stayed with him at his seat Firle Place, near Lewes, several times.

places.name: Pantano Borghese
places.description: On the outskirts of Rome south of Tivoli, an estate that since 1613 has belonged to the Borghese family.

places.name: Marcigliana
places.description: A protected rural area to the north-east of Rome, now a nature reserve.

places.name: Malafede
places.description: Decima Malafede is a nature reserve within the district of Rome.

persons.name: Titus CaesarVespasianus
persons.description: Roman emperor from 79 to 81.

persons.name: William HydeWollaston
persons.description: Originally a physician he became a prominent chemist, physicist and physiologist isolating the chemical elements osmium, palladium and rhodium. He made his fortune by developing a method of obtaining metallic platinum. A friend and to some extent a rival of Davy's, in 1820 he served briefly as President of the Royal Society of London between Banks's death and Davy's election. FRSL.

places.name: Pozzuoli
places.description: A city and region in the Italian region of Campania. The source for Pozzuoli Red, a natural earth pigment that was originally found in the volcanic areas of the region.

persons.name: Roger JosephBoscovich
persons.description: Physicist, astronomer and mathematician born in Croatia but lived and worked mainly in Italy and France. Boscovich's work makes him one of the forerunners of atomic theory.

persons.name: Pythagoras
persons.description: Pythagoras of Samos was an ancient Ionian Greek philosopher, polymath, and the eponymous founder of Pythagoreanism. Believed in the primacy of number.

persons.name: Democritus
persons.description: Pre-Socratic Greek philosopher who proposed a form of atomism.

places.name: Herculaneum
places.description: Herculaneum was an ancient Roman town, located in the modern-day comune of Ercolano, Campania, Italy.

places.name: Rome
places.description: The capital of Italy.

persons.name: Carl WilhelmScheele
persons.description: Swedish-German pharmaceutical chemist. One of the discoverers of what would later be called oxygen (1771) as well as other chemical elements including what Davy renamed chlorine.

persons.name: Antoine-LaurentLavoisier
persons.description: French chemist and tax farmer (for which he was guillotined). Developed a new nomenclature for chemistry (much of which is still in use today) and argued strongly against the existence of phlogiston. Davy read some of his writings while in Cornwall which he then opposed and throughout his career maintained an ambivalent attitude towards Lavoisierian chemisty. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Claude LouisBerthollet
persons.description: French Chemist. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Joseph LouisGay-Lussac
persons.description: French chemist and physicist, known mostly for his discovery that water is made of two parts hydrogen and one part oxygen by volume (with Alexander von Humboldt), for two laws related to gases, and for his work on alcohol-water mixtures. Became involved in controversies with Davy over various chemical discoveries. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Louis JacquesThénard
persons.description: Held chairs of chemistry at the Collège de France and the Ecole Polytechnique. Worked closely with Gay-Lussac and met Davy in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

places.name: Geneva
places.description: Geneva is a city in Switzerland on the border with France.

persons.name: Joseph LouisGay-Lussac
persons.description: French chemist and physicist, known mostly for his discovery that water is made of two parts hydrogen and one part oxygen by volume (with Alexander von Humboldt), for two laws related to gases, and for his work on alcohol-water mixtures. Became involved in controversies with Davy over various chemical discoveries. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Joseph LouisGay-Lussac
persons.description: French chemist and physicist, known mostly for his discovery that water is made of two parts hydrogen and one part oxygen by volume (with Alexander von Humboldt), for two laws related to gases, and for his work on alcohol-water mixtures. Became involved in controversies with Davy over various chemical discoveries. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Joseph FrédéricBérard
persons.description: French physician and philosopher in Montpellier where Davy met him on his Continental tour.

places.name: Montpellier
places.description: A city in southern France.

places.name: Languedoc
places.description: Languedoc is a historical province of France located on the south coast.

persons.name: DomenicoViviani
persons.description: Italian botanist; Professor of Botany at the University of Genoa.

places.name: Genoa
places.description: Italian port city in northwestern Italy. It is the capital of the Liguria region.

places.name: Sestri Levante
places.description: Sestri Levante is a town with the city of Genoa, Liguria, in Italy.

places.name: Mediterranean Sea
places.description: Connected to the Atlantic Ocean and almost completely surrounded by land.

persons.name: NicolasClément
persons.description: French chemist who worked with his father-in-law, Charles Desormes.

persons.name: CharlesDesormes
persons.description: Desormes was a French physicist and chemist. He did most of his scientific work in collaboration with his son-in-law, Nicolas Clément.

persons.name: NicolasClément
persons.description: French chemist who worked with his father-in-law, Charles Desormes.

persons.name: CharlesDesormes
persons.description: Desormes was a French physicist and chemist. He did most of his scientific work in collaboration with his son-in-law, Nicolas Clément.

persons.name: NicolasClément
persons.description: French chemist who worked with his father-in-law, Charles Desormes.

persons.name: Joseph LouisGay-Lussac
persons.description: French chemist and physicist, known mostly for his discovery that water is made of two parts hydrogen and one part oxygen by volume (with Alexander von Humboldt), for two laws related to gases, and for his work on alcohol-water mixtures. Became involved in controversies with Davy over various chemical discoveries. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: André-MarieAmpère
persons.description: French physicist and mathematician and one of the key figure in the early study of electro-magnetism. Davy met him in Paris in 1813 and they developed a scientific rivalry. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: BernardCourtois
persons.description: French chemist who first isolated iodine. though he did not recognise it as an element which Davy did whilst in Paris.

persons.name: NicolasClément
persons.description: French chemist who worked with his father-in-law, Charles Desormes.

persons.name: CharlesDesormes
persons.description: Desormes was a French physicist and chemist. He did most of his scientific work in collaboration with his son-in-law, Nicolas Clément.

places.name: Albulae Aquae
places.description: White Waters'; a group of springs to the west of Tivolo, Italy, and location of an ancient Roman settlement.

persons.name: WilliamHenry
persons.description: Manchester physician and chemist, whose Elements of Experimental Chemistry went through eleven editions. FRSL.

persons.name: LuigiGalvani
persons.description: Italian surgeon and anatomist who carried out experiments with electricity and animals. The term 'galvanism' was named after him to refer to the generation of electric current by chemical action.

places.name: Geneva
places.description: Geneva is a city in Switzerland on the border with France.

persons.name: Nicolas-Théodore deSaussure
persons.description: Swiss chemist and student of plant physiology who made seminal advances in phytochemistry. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Joseph LouisGay-Lussac
persons.description: French chemist and physicist, known mostly for his discovery that water is made of two parts hydrogen and one part oxygen by volume (with Alexander von Humboldt), for two laws related to gases, and for his work on alcohol-water mixtures. Became involved in controversies with Davy over various chemical discoveries. ForMemRSL.

places.name: Geneva
places.description: Geneva is a city in Switzerland on the border with France.

places.name: Pézenas
places.description: Pézenas is a commune in the Herault department of southern France, close to Saint-Thibéry.

places.name: St Thibery
places.description: Saint-Thibéry is a commune in the Hérault department in the Occitanie region of southern France. The village of Saint-Thibéry is built at the confluence of the Rivers Thongue and Hérault.

places.name: Geneva
places.description: Geneva is a city in Switzerland on the border with France.

persons.name: JosephBanks
persons.description: A member of the Lincolnshire gentry, Banks sailed as a botanist on James Cook's first voyage to the Pacific (1768-1771). Elected President of the Royal Society of London in 1778 he served for forty-two years until just before his death. The dominant figure in the running of English science during that time, he became one of Davy's patrons and ultimately Davy succeeded him to the Presidency. FRSL.

places.name: Montpellier
places.description: A city in southern France.

places.name: Languedoc
places.description: Languedoc is a historical province of France located on the south coast.

places.name: Provence
places.description: Provence is a region in southeastern France which borders the Mediterranean Sea and Italy.

places.name: Pézenas
places.description: Pézenas is a commune in the Herault department of southern France, close to Saint-Thibéry.

persons.name: NicolasClément
persons.description: French chemist who worked with his father-in-law, Charles Desormes.

persons.name: CharlesDesormes
persons.description: Desormes was a French physicist and chemist. He did most of his scientific work in collaboration with his son-in-law, Nicolas Clément.

places.name: Genoa
places.description: Italian port city in northwestern Italy. It is the capital of the Liguria region.

places.name: Liguria
places.description: Liguria is a region of north west Italy. Its capital is Genoa.

places.name: Porto fino
places.description: A coastal town in north-western Italy, within the city of Genoa.

places.name: Genoa
places.description: Italian port city in northwestern Italy. It is the capital of the Liguria region.

places.name: Sestri Levante
places.description: Sestri Levante is a town with the city of Genoa, Liguria, in Italy.

places.name: Alps
places.description: The Alps are the highest and most extensive mountain range that lies entirely in Europe. They are located in eight European countries.

places.name: Apennines
places.description: The Apennines are a range of mountains that run down the spine of peninsular Italy.

places.name: Sestri Levante
places.description: Sestri Levante is a town with the city of Genoa, Liguria, in Italy.

places.name: Sestri Levante
places.description: Sestri Levante is a town with the city of Genoa, Liguria, in Italy.

places.name: Chiavari
places.description: Chiavari is a seaside municipality in the Ligurian region of Italy.

places.name: Porto fino
places.description: A coastal town in north-western Italy, within the city of Genoa.

places.name: Florence
places.description: The capital city of the Italian region of Tuscany.

persons.name: Claude LouisBerthollet
persons.description: French Chemist. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Michel EugèneChevreul
persons.description: French organic chemist. Met Davy when he was in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Jöns JacobBerzelius
persons.description: Swedish chemist. He discovered the chemical elements cerium and selenium, and was the first to isolate silicon, thorium, titanium, and zirconium. A rival of Davy's whom he met a few times.

persons.name: Jöns JacobBerzelius
persons.description: Swedish chemist. He discovered the chemical elements cerium and selenium, and was the first to isolate silicon, thorium, titanium, and zirconium. A rival of Davy's whom he met a few times.

persons.name: Michel EugèneChevreul
persons.description: French organic chemist. Met Davy when he was in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Jöns JacobBerzelius
persons.description: Swedish chemist. He discovered the chemical elements cerium and selenium, and was the first to isolate silicon, thorium, titanium, and zirconium. A rival of Davy's whom he met a few times.

persons.name: Louis NicolasVauquelin
persons.description: French pharmacist and chemist who met Davy in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Martin HeinrichKlaproth
persons.description: Pharmacist and chemist. Professor of Chemistry in Berlin. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Michel EugèneChevreul
persons.description: French organic chemist. Met Davy when he was in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Jöns JacobBerzelius
persons.description: Swedish chemist. He discovered the chemical elements cerium and selenium, and was the first to isolate silicon, thorium, titanium, and zirconium. A rival of Davy's whom he met a few times.

persons.name: Joseph LouisGay-Lussac
persons.description: French chemist and physicist, known mostly for his discovery that water is made of two parts hydrogen and one part oxygen by volume (with Alexander von Humboldt), for two laws related to gases, and for his work on alcohol-water mixtures. Became involved in controversies with Davy over various chemical discoveries. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: François-Étiennede La Roche
persons.description: Genevan physician, naturalist, chemist, botanist, and ichthyologist.

persons.name: Daniel GabrielFahrenheit
persons.description: German physicist, inventor, and scientific instrument maker, who invented the mercury-in-glass thermometer. The temperature scale he proposed is named after him. ForMemRSL.

works.name: Researches chemical and philosophical: chiefly concerning nitrous oxide or dephlogisticated nitrous air and its respiration
works.author: Humphry Davy

persons.name: Pierre-SimonLaplace
persons.description: French mathematician seen as the Newton of France. He met Davy in 1813 and 1820. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Antoine-LaurentLavoisier
persons.description: French chemist and tax farmer (for which he was guillotined). Developed a new nomenclature for chemistry (much of which is still in use today) and argued strongly against the existence of phlogiston. Davy read some of his writings while in Cornwall which he then opposed and throughout his career maintained an ambivalent attitude towards Lavoisierian chemisty. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: RichardChenevix
persons.description: Irish chemist, mineralogist and playwright. He was known for his sharp cynicism and for engaging in combative criticism. FRSL.

persons.name: Johann FriedrichJohn
persons.description: German chemist and pharmacist.

persons.name: Antoine-Francois deFourcroy
persons.description: French chemist who collaborated with Lavoisier in standardising chemical nomenclature. Davy as a teenager read some of his work.

persons.name: Martin HeinrichKlaproth
persons.description: Pharmacist and chemist. Professor of Chemistry in Berlin. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Johann GeorgTralles
persons.description: German mathematician and physicist

persons.name: Joseph LouisGay-Lussac
persons.description: French chemist and physicist, known mostly for his discovery that water is made of two parts hydrogen and one part oxygen by volume (with Alexander von Humboldt), for two laws related to gases, and for his work on alcohol-water mixtures. Became involved in controversies with Davy over various chemical discoveries. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: RichardKirwan
persons.description: Irish chemist, mineralogist and geologist who accused fellow geologist, James Hutton, of atheism following publication of his Theory of the Earth (1788). FRSL

persons.name: Louis JacquesThénard
persons.description: Held chairs of chemistry at the Collège de France and the Ecole Polytechnique. Worked closely with Gay-Lussac and met Davy in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Claude LouisBerthollet
persons.description: French Chemist. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Jean-BaptisteBiot
persons.description: French mathematician, physicist and astronomer; Professor of Physics at the Collège de France. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Dominique François JeanArago
persons.description: French mathematician, physicist, astronomer and political liberal. Davy presented him with the Copley Medal in 1825. ForMemRSL.

works.name: Mémoires de Physique et de Chimie, de la Société d'Arcueil
works.author: Gay Lussac

persons.name: Joseph LouisGay-Lussac
persons.description: French chemist and physicist, known mostly for his discovery that water is made of two parts hydrogen and one part oxygen by volume (with Alexander von Humboldt), for two laws related to gases, and for his work on alcohol-water mixtures. Became involved in controversies with Davy over various chemical discoveries. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Louis JacquesThénard
persons.description: Held chairs of chemistry at the Collège de France and the Ecole Polytechnique. Worked closely with Gay-Lussac and met Davy in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Claude LouisBerthollet
persons.description: French Chemist. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: NapoleonBuonaparte
persons.description: French general and, as First Consul, 1799-1804, and Emperor, 1804-1815, military dictator of France and the territories it occupied. Established the Volta prize for research electricity and provided Davy with a passport to collect it in Paris in 1813.

places.name: Aix-en-Provence
places.description: Aix is a town in southern France, once the capital of the region of Provence.

places.name: Ballachulish
places.description: Also known as Ballyhulish. A village in the Lochaber region of western Scotland.

places.name: Mayenne
places.description: Mayenne is a department in north-west France.

places.name: Marseille
places.description: The second largest city in France and located on the Mediterranean coast.

places.name: Laval, Mayenne
places.description: Laval is the capital town of the Mayenne department in north-west France.

places.name: Yorkshire
places.description: Yorkshire is a historic county in northern England and the largest by area size in the United Kingdom.

persons.name: GeorgePearson
persons.description: Physician and chemist who introduced a new systematic nomenclature for inorganic chemistry in English based on that devised by French chemists and confirmed the effacy of vaccination. FRSL.

places.name: Rome
places.description: The capital of Italy.

places.name: Pyrenees
places.description: The Pyrenees mountain range separates the Iberian Peninsula from the rest of Europe, stretching more than 430km between Spain and France and rising higher than 3,400m in elevation.

places.name: Canigou
places.description: A mountain peak located in the Pyrenees of southern France. Davy made sketches and wrote a poem about The Canigou in notebook 14I.

persons.name: Heinrich AugustVogel
persons.description: Professor of Chemistry at the University of Munich.

places.name: Albulae Aquae
places.description: White Waters'; a group of springs to the west of Tivolo, Italy, and location of an ancient Roman settlement.

places.name: Paestum
places.description: Paestum was an ancient Greek city on the coast of southern Italy.

persons.name: Edme-FrançoisJomard
persons.description: French cartographer, engineer, and archaeologist. He was a member of the Institut d'Egypte established by Napoleon.

persons.name: André-MarieAmpère
persons.description: French physicist and mathematician and one of the key figure in the early study of electro-magnetism. Davy met him in Paris in 1813 and they developed a scientific rivalry. ForMemRSL.

places.name: Rue de Bourgogne No. 28
places.description: The address of the apartment where Edme-François Jomard, French engineer and archaelogist, lived.

places.name: Cour du commerce
places.description: Cour du commerce is a Parisian passageway that dates back to 1776. It was a meeting place for intellectuals and revolutionaries. It now houses shops and one of Paris' oldest restaurants.

persons.name: MichaelFaraday
persons.description: From 1812 Davy used Faraday as his amanuensis and the following year secured his appointment as laboratory assistant at the Royal Institution. Despite a difficult relationship with Davy, Faraday later became the dominant figure at the Royal Institution and one of the leading scientific personalities of the middle third of the nineteenth century. FRSL.

persons.name: JaneDavy
persons.description: Daughter of Charles Kerr, an Antiguan merchant who made his fortune in highly dubious circumstances. Following his death she moved to Britain where she married Schukbrugh Apreece who died in 1807. After running a successful literary salon in Edinburgh she moved to London where she met Davy and they married on 11 April 1812 two days after he had been knighted by the Prince Regent.

persons.name: WilliamKerr
persons.description: Dates untraced; the nephew of Jane Davy's uncle, William Kerr (1738-1824), a physican of Northampton; one of Jane Davy's executors who had been a medical student at the University of Edinburgh and later a physician and assistant surgeon.

places.name: Lesketh How
places.description: Built in 1844, and since redeveloped, Lesketh-How was the house near Ambleside, in the Lake District, where Davy's brother, the physician John Davy, lived. John Davy died there in January 1868.

places.name: France
places.description: France, officially the French Republic, is a country located primarily in Western Europe.
